problem: Sam the Sham is an unfair shoe salesman. He has a pair of shoes that was priced at $\$60$ last week. To entice customers, he wants to put a "$25\%$ off'' tag on the shoes but he still wants the customer to pay $\$60$ for the shoes. He raises the price of the shoes so that after the $25\%$ discount the shoes will cost $\$60$. In dollars, what must the new price of the shoes be before the discount?
solution: Let the new price of the shoes be $x$. We are told that after a $25\%$ discount, the shoes cost 60 dollars. Thus, $\frac{3}{4}x = 60$. It follows that $x = \boxed{80}$.
model_solution:
Let $x$ be the price of the shoes after the discount is applied.
\(\begin{array}{l}\text { Let } x \text { be the price of the shoes after the discount is applied. }\\x=.75(60) \\\end{array}\)
\(\begin{array}{l}\text { Let } x \text { be the price of the shoes after the discount is applied. }\\x=.75(60) \\x=45 \\x=45 \cdot 4 \\x=180\end{array}\)
Let \(p\) be the original price of the shoes.
\(x=.75 p\)
\(\begin{array}{l}p=180 / .75 \\p=240\end{array}\)
\(p=240\)
\(\begin{array}{l}x=.75 p \\60=x \\60=.75 p \\60 / .75=p\end{array}\)
\(\begin{array}{l}p=60 / .75 \\p=80\end{array}\)
\(\begin{array}{l}60 / .75=p \\60 / .75=80\end{array}\)
\(x=1.33(60) \)
\(x=80\)
steps:
Let $x$ be the price of the shoes after the discount is applied.
\(\begin{array}{l}\text { Let } x \text { be the price of the shoes after the discount is applied. }\\x=.75(60) \\\end{array}\)
\(\begin{array}{l}\text { Let } x \text { be the price of the shoes after the discount is applied. }\\x=.75(60) \\x=45 \\x=45 \cdot 4 \\x=180\end{array}\)

Let \(p\) be the original price of the shoes.
\(x=.75 p\)

\(\begin{array}{l}\text { Let } x \text { be the price of the shoes after the discount is applied. }\\x=.75(60) \\x=45 \\x=45 \cdot 4 \\x=180\end{array}\)

Let \(p\) be the original price of the shoes.
\(x=.75 p\)
